authors: Araújo, J., Cai, J., Stevens, J.
key_finding: Only 12.2% of American adults (age 20+) are metabolically healthy using contemporary metabolic health criteria; prevalence increases to 19.9% using older ATP III definitions
authors_full: Araújo, Joana; Cai, Jianwen; Stevens, June
title: Prevalence of Optimal Metabolic Health in American Adults: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 2009–2016
population: US adults age 20+; n=16,914 participants; nationally representative

effect_sizes.description: Percentage of US adults classified as metabolically healthy using current metabolic health definitions
Percentage of US adults classified as metabolically healthy using older ATP III metabolic syndrome criteria

notes: Key study demonstrating the rarity of metabolic health in American adults; used composite criteria including fasting glucose, fasting insulin, triglycerides, and HDL

authors: Mottillo, S., Filion, K.B., Genest, J., et al.
key_finding: Metabolic syndrome associated with 2-fold increased cardiovascular risk and 1.5-fold increased all-cause mortality; analyzed 87 studies with 951,083 patients
authors_full: Mottillo, Salvatore; Filion, Kristian B.; Genest, Jacques; et al.
title: The Metabolic Syndrome and Cardiovascular Risk: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
journal: Journal of the American College of Cardiology
study_design_detail: Systematic review and meta-analysis of prospective observational studies
population: Mixed populations from 87 prospective cohort studies; 951,083 total participants

effect_sizes.description: Relative risk of CVD outcomes with metabolic syndrome
Relative risk of all-cause mortality with metabolic syndrome

notes: Major meta-analysis demonstrating metabolic syndrome as strong predictor of mortality; analyzed both NCEP and revised NCEP definitions

authors: Kramer, C.K., Zinman, B., Retnakaran, R.
key_finding: Metabolically healthy obese individuals have 24% higher risk of cardiovascular events and all-cause mortality vs metabolically healthy normal-weight individuals (RR 1.24 over 10+ years)
authors_full: Kramer, Caroline K.; Zinman, Bernard; Retnakaran, Ravi
title: Are Metabolically Healthy Overweight and Obesity Benign Conditions? A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
study_design_detail: Systematic review and meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies
population: 8 studies evaluating metabolically healthy obese vs normal-weight individuals; n=61,386 with 3,988 CVD/mortality events

effect_sizes.description: Risk in metabolically healthy obese vs metabolically healthy normal-weight (≥10 years follow-up)

primary_outcome: Cardiovascular events and all-cause mortality in metabolically healthy obese individuals
notes: Demonstrates that metabolic health status does not eliminate excess mortality risk from obesity; relevant for understanding metabolic health limitations

authors: Ljungman, S., Wikstrand, J., Hartford, M., et al.
key_finding: Hyperinsulinemia (fasting insulin) independently predicts all-cause mortality and ischemic heart disease in nondiabetic men; 1.58-fold increased risk at highest vs lowest quartile
authors_full: Ljungman, Soren; Wikstrand, Jorgen; Hartford, Mats; et al.
title: Hyperinsulinaemia as long-term predictor of death and ischaemic heart disease in nondiabetic men: The Malmö Preventive Project
study_design_detail: Prospective cohort study of initially healthy middle-aged men
population: Nondiabetic Swedish males; n=6,074; baseline age 46-49 years

effect_sizes.description: Top vs bottom quartile fasting insulin, 19-year follow-up
Top vs bottom quartile fasting insulin

notes: Demonstrates fasting insulin as independent mortality predictor; shows early insulin resistance as risk marker before diabetes development

authors: Karelis, A.D., St-Pierre, D.H., Conus, F., et al.
key_finding: Metabolically healthy obese phenotype defined by stringent criteria (HOMA-IR ≤2.8, triglycerides ≤150 mg/dL, HDL ≥50 mg/dL) represents distinct subgroup; lower prevalence using strict vs loose definitions
authors_full: Karelis, Antony D.; St-Pierre, Denis H.; Conus, Francoise; et al.
title: Relationship Between Low-Grade Inflammation and Insulin Resistance in Obese Women: Effects of Diet and Exercise
study_design_detail: Cross-sectional analysis establishing metabolic health criteria
population: Obese women; n=38; mean BMI 34.8 kg/m²

effect_sizes.description: Relationship between insulin resistance and inflammation markers

primary_outcome: Definition and characterization of metabolically healthy obese phenotype
secondary_outcomes: Relationship between insulin resistance and inflammation
notes: Foundational study establishing stringent Karelis criteria for metabolic health including triglycerides and HDL; demonstrates rarity of metabolic health in obese populations

authors: Wang, Y., Sun, D., Vendemiale, G., et al.
key_finding: Plasma metabolites of a healthy lifestyle associated with 17% lower all-cause mortality risk and 25% higher likelihood of reaching age 85 (longevity); healthy metabolomic signature reflects optimal lipid metabolism
authors_full: Wang, Yujing; Sun, Dong; Vendemiale, Gianluigi; et al.
title: Plasma metabolites of a healthy lifestyle in relation to mortality and longevity: Four prospective US cohort studies
study_design_detail: Analysis of 4 prospective US cohorts with metabolomic data
population: Nurses' Health Study, Nurses' Health Study II, Health Professionals Follow-up Study; n combined >100,000

effect_sizes.description: Healthy metabolomic signature vs worst signature (17% lower mortality)

notes: Recent comprehensive analysis showing metabolic health markers (lipid metabolism) associated with longevity; includes major US cohort studies

key_finding: Proposed syndrome X (metabolic syndrome) centered on insulin resistance with constellation of related metabolic abnormalities including elevated triglycerides, low HDL, hypertension, and hyperglycemia
title: Banting Lecture 1988: Role of Insulin Resistance in Human Disease
study_design_detail: Seminal review establishing metabolic syndrome concept
population: Theoretical framework based on clinical observation
notes: Landmark paper coining term 'Syndrome X'; established insulin resistance as central mechanism linking triglycerides, HDL, glucose, hypertension, and cardiovascular risk

authors: Diabetes Epidemiology: Collaborative Analysis of Diagnostic Criteria in Europe
key_finding: Fasting glucose continuously and independently associated with vascular disease risk across all concentrations (including below diabetes threshold of 7 mmol/L); risk increases linearly from normal glucose
authors_full: Diabetes Epidemiology: Collaborative Analysis of Diagnostic Criteria in Europe
title: Glucose tolerance and cardiovascular mortality: comparison of fasting and 2-hour post-challenge glucose criteria
study_design_detail: Meta-analysis of prospective studies examining glucose thresholds
population: Multiple prospective cohorts with glucose measurements; combined n>1 million

effect_sizes.description: Fasting glucose risk gradient across entire glucose spectrum

notes: Demonstrates lack of glucose threshold; risk evident even within 'normal' fasting glucose range; important for understanding fasting glucose as continuous risk marker
